data.title: Henry IV of France lives, where do his kids marry?
data.meta_description: So this came from a convo I had with @Kellan Sullivan , in a scenario where Henry IV of France isn’t assassinated and instead lives on to see his kids grow...
data.text:
So this came from a convo I had with @Kellan Sullivan , in a scenario where Henry IV of France isn’t assassinated and instead lives on to see his kids grow up, how likelt is it that his kids make completely different marriages? For instance, Louis XIII could be married to Lorraine to tie that area closer to France, whilst elisabeth of France May marry to England.

Now I know @isabella is a big fan of elisabeth marrying into savoy here, and whilst elisabeth was betrothed ro the heir to savoy until his death in 1605, she was never betrothed ro the new heir, and a part of me does Think that if englsnd comes knocking offering the prince of wales as a groom, henri is going to take their offer up. Better afuture queen than a mere duchess, especially when Philip iv is born.

so say elisabeth is betrothed to the prince of wales in 1615, and then marries him at the end of the decade, what consequences could rhere be? Elisabeth seems to be pretty politically astute and good at winning people over, could she habe an easier time of it than her sister did otl?

Elisabeth seems to be pretty politically astute and good at winning people over, could she habe an easier time of it than her sister did otl?

This could be a really interesting change. Are there any indication how religious Elisabeth was? Would she convert for politics? (Something Henrietta Maria wouldn't have done) And even if she didn't convert, just not flaunting Catholicism and not getting involved in the religious debates would have gone a long way to keeping things calm.

And there are no indications I can find that Elisabeth had the money problems her sister did, this would also help.

Another change would be to the character of Louis XIII. Having Henry around to teach him how to be king, would be a big change.

I took a stab at a family tree. Let me know what you think

HRM Henry IV Bourbon, King of France (1553-1524) married firstly Margaret de Valois, no issue; married secondly Marie de Medici, had issue

HRM Louis XIII Bourbon, King of France (1601-) married firstly HRH Nicole de Lorraine, Princess of France (1608-1622) and had issue; married secondly HRM Marie de Bourbon-Montpensier, Queen of France, Duchess of Montpensier (1605-) and had issue​

​

​

HRH Margaret de Bourbon, Madame Royale (1622-)​

​

Archduchess Christina Anna of Austria (1635-1652)​

Archduke Leopold Henry of Austria (1641-)​

​

HRH Francis de Bourbon, (1613-) married HG Beatrice Louise of Savoy (1615-) and had issue​

​

HG Charles Louis de Bourbon, Duke of Savoy (1633-)​

This could be a really interesting change. Are there any indication how religious Elisabeth was? Would she convert for politics? (Something Henrietta Maria wouldn't have done) And even if she didn't convert, just not flaunting Catholicism and not getting involved in the religious debates would have gone a long way to keeping things calm.

And there are no indications I can find that Elisabeth had the money problems her sister did, this would also help.

Another change would be to the character of Louis XIII. Having Henry around to teach him how to be king, would be a big change.

I’m not sure if she would convert it is possible that having her father around could make her much more practical no?

Could have more kids too. Henrietta Maria was the last in 1609 and Henri died in 1610.

Definitely always a bonus

His approach toward Protestants, in particular, could be very different. IOTL his mother despised them, removed them from the government, and raised Louis to distrust them as a fifth column within his kingdom. ITTL the Huguenot rebellions of the 1620s might be avoided.

so the Huguenot persecution of orl which prompted siastorous English involvement could be removed?

I took a stab at a family tree. Let me know what you think

Couple things:

I find it odd that Charles-Élise have fewer surviving kids than Louis XIII and his Lorrainer wife or Christine de France and Felipe IV of Spain, when both Louis and Christine would be far closer relations (Maria de Medici and Margarethe of Austria were cousins, Maria de Medici was Nicole's aunt) to their spouse (Charles-Élise's closest relative would be Henri IV's paternal grandfather who was brother to Mary, Queen of Scots' maternal grandmother).

Maximilian I of Bavaria would be HSH not HEH (I'm assuming the E is for Electoral), since pre-18th centuries the electors had the rank of "His Serene Highness". The duke of Savoy would be "HH" not "HG" (which I'm assuming is "His Grace")

Louis XIII isn't marrying Madame de Montpensier, her marriage was engineered first to his brother, Nicolas then to Gaston as a way of providing the guy with estates (IIRC the first was done by Henri himself). If Louis is without a wife in the mid-1620s and Henri IV is the one doing the arranging, why not Nicole's sister, Claude?

Too many Habsburg matches. Henri really didn't like them, and the Spanish matches of 1615 were Maria de Medici's doing. So even if Christine marries Felipe, I don't see Jeanne marrying Ferdinand II (especially since then we end up with three unmarried Habsburg girls - Anne of Austria and her sister; and Maria Anna of Austria, Electress of Bavaria). Maybe an Italian match with Tuscany as is often kicked around for Henriette

I find it odd that Charles-Élise have fewer surviving kids than Louis XIII and his Lorrainer wife or Christine de France and Felipe IV of Spain, when both Louis and Christine would be far closer relations (Maria de Medici and Margarethe of Austria were cousins, Maria de Medici was Nicole's aunt) to their spouse (Charles-Élise's closest relative would be Henri IV's paternal grandfather who was brother to Mary, Queen of Scots' maternal grandmother).

So even if Christine marries Felipe, I don't see Jeanne marrying Ferdinand II (especially since then we end up with three unmarried Habsburg girls - Anne of Austria and her sister; and Maria Anna of Austria, Electress of Bavaria). Maybe an Italian match with Tuscany as is often kicked around for Henriette

How many would be realistic for Charlie abd Elisabeth, in your view?

I find it odd that Charles-Élise have fewer surviving kids than Louis XIII and his Lorrainer wife

I randomly generated the kids. Good point about how closely they are related.

Maximilian I of Bavaria would be HSH not HEH (I'm assuming the E is for Electoral), since pre-18th centuries the electors had the rank of "His Serene Highness". The duke of Savoy would be "HH" not "HG" (which I'm assuming is "His Grace")

Thanks

Louis XIII isn't marrying Madame de Montpensier, her marriage was engineered first to his brother, Nicolas then to Gaston as a way of providing the guy with estates (IIRC the first was done by Henri himself). If Louis is without a wife in the mid-1620s and Henri IV is the one doing the arranging, why not Nicole's sister, Claude?

So, OTL Gaston really didn't want to marry Madame de Montpensier, and this would be right after Henry IV died, so my thought process was a grieving Louis, after fighting with his brother, was like "fine, I'll marry her." But mostly I just really felt she got the short end of the stick OTL and wanted her to be Queen.

Maybe an Italian match with Tuscany as is often kicked around for Henriette

Do you mean Jeanne? Or would Henriette not be married to Savoy and then Bravaria?

For instance, Louis XIII could be married to Lorraine to tie that area closer to France, whilst elisabeth of France May marry to England.

Better afuture queen than a mere duchess, especially when Philip iv is born.

so say elisabeth is betrothed to the prince of wales in 1615, and then marries him at the end of the decade, what consequences could rhere be? Elisabeth seems to be pretty politically astute and good at winning people over, could she habe an easier time of it than her sister did otl?

Well I still think the Savoy match more likely but I guess who if Elisabeth’s new engagement in England is just after the death of her first fiancé it can work...

If Louis married Nicole, heiress of Lorraine, no way who Lorraine will go to someone different from their children

No way who Henry IV will consent to any Spanish match for his children... maybe an Austrian match but not Spanish... so if Elisabeth will marry in England, the Savoy match will go to Christine as OTL .

Nicole, Duchess of Lorraine is a great match for Louis XIII and no way France will let go Lorraine if she died (most likely she and Louis will have a wedding contract much similar to the one between Charles VIII had and Anne of Brittany), specially if they had children. The Montpensier match will still go to Gaston as he is the one who need lands and a simple noblewoman is not good enough for the King, no matter how rich she is

Do you mean Jeanne? Or would Henriette not be married to Savoy and then Bavaria?

Henriette would likely be matched with Grand Duke Ferdinando II de Medici if there are no other "kings" available (although there was a TL where she wound up married to Wladyslaw IV of Poland; and another one where she ended up with Frederik Hendrik of the Netherlands). Jeanne would get whoever's left. Another option for Jeanne might be the Winter Queen's eldest son (James VI was trying to get an Austrian archduchess - Cäcilie Renata - for his grandson, Heinrich Friedrich) but if there's no 30YW analogue or Cäcilie's not available, a French princess might be possible - if doubtful, since Henri IV & James VI would be dead by this point, although the Winter Queen did try to get Prince Rupert married to the duchesse de Rohan while during the Fronde there was talk of an uncle of George I marrying a French princess (one of the Chevreuse girls I think) and Wladyslaw IV marrying Madame de Guise.

Gaston marrying inside France seems weird if his brother is too. OTL there was talk of a match between Gaston and Louise Marie Gonzaga (OTL Queen of Poland) that went tits up because of Maria de Medici's personal dislike of the Gonzaga girl's dad who had once passed a remark about the "newness" of the Medicis (which given that Henri IV's one mistress used to refer to Maria as his "fat Florentine banker" sorta makes sense why she didn't like it). There were also proposed matches between Gaston and Anna de Medici and Anna Konstancja of Poland.

Gaston marrying inside France seems weird if his brother is too. OTL there was talk of a match between Gaston and Louise Marie Gonzaga (OTL Queen of Poland) that went tits up because of Maria de Medici's personal dislike of the Gonzaga girl's dad who had once passed a remark about the "newness" of the Medicis (which given that Henri IV's one mistress used to refer to Maria as his "fat Florentine banker" sorta makes sense why she didn't like it). There were also proposed matches between Gaston and Anna de Medici and Anna Konstancja of Poland.

Well a domestic match for the King make no sense so Louis will marry foreign (Nicole of Lorraine is a foreign match and she would bring Lorraine to France as dowry so she make more sense than anyone else if Henry IV can get her)

The Montpensier match will still go to Gaston as he is the one who need lands and a simple noblewoman is not good enough for the King, no matter how rich she is

So, Gaston is Duke of Orléans, so I don't think he needs lands. And about Louis marrying her, my thoughts as stated above were:

OTL Gaston really didn't want to marry Madame de Montpensier, and this would be right after Henry IV died, so my thought process was a grieving Louis, after fighting with his brother, was like "fine, I'll marry her." But mostly I just really felt she got the short end of the stick OTL and wanted her to be Queen.

And while French monarchs rarely married native noblewoman, other monarchs did from time to time, it's hardly infeasible.
